meta.description: Generic event cards - shuffled deck, one revealed per era. Events are archetypes with real historical examples.

events.name: Ice Age
events.description: Glaciers grind southward as Earth's orbit wobbles. Sea levels plummet 100 meters, locking water into continent-spanning ice sheets. Tropical zones contract toward the equator; shallow seas drain away.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: Milankovitch cycles alter Earth's tilt and orbit over 100,000-year periods. When ice sheets grow, they reflect sunlight, amplifying cooling. Glacial maxima lock up 3% of all ocean water.
real_examples: End-Ordovician (~445 MYA) - Gondwana glaciation killed 85% of marine species
Pleistocene Ice Ages (~2.6 MYA - 11,700 ya) - Mammoths, ground sloths, and sabertooths vanish

events.name: Volcanic Winter
events.description: The sky turns to ash. Flood basalts pour across millions of square kilometers, ejecting sulfur dioxide that blocks the sun. Temperatures crash, then swing into greenhouse overdrive as CO2 accumulates.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: Large Igneous Provinces erupt for hundreds of thousands of years. Sulfuric acid rain devastates vegetation. The initial freeze gives way to CO2-driven warming that can persist for millennia.
real_examples: Siberian Traps (~252 MYA) - The Great Dying: 96% of species exterminated
Deccan Traps (~66 MYA) - Million-year eruption stressed ecosystems before the asteroid

events.name: Asteroid Impact
events.description: A mountain-sized rock screams through the atmosphere at 20 km/s. The impact liquefies bedrock, launches debris worldwide, and ignites continental wildfires. Earth plunges into years of darkness as photosynthesis halts.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: A 10km impactor releases energy equivalent to billions of nuclear bombs. Ejecta reentering the atmosphere heats it like an oven. Soot and dust block sunlight for 2-10 years.
real_examples: Chicxulub Impact (~66 MYA) - 180km crater in Yucatan ended the dinosaurs' reign
Sudbury Impact (~1.85 BYA) - 250km crater, one of Earth's largest confirmed impacts

events.name: Ocean Anoxia
events.description: The oceans suffocate. Warming waters hold less oxygen; stagnant circulation lets dead zones expand. Hydrogen sulfide rises from the deep, poisoning marine life and staining the seas purple.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: Oceanic Anoxic Events occur when circulation stalls. Sulfate-reducing bacteria thrive in oxygen-depleted waters, producing toxic H2S that can escape into the atmosphere.
real_examples: Late Devonian Kellwasser Event (~372 MYA) - Eliminated 75% of species over 2 million years
Toarcian OAE (~183 MYA) - Black shales record global oxygen crash

events.name: Global Warming
events.description: Runaway greenhouse gases push temperatures beyond tolerance limits. Oceans acidify as they absorb CO2, dissolving shells. Heat stress becomes inescapable; equatorial regions become uninhabitable dead zones.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: Every 1°C warming shifts climate zones ~150km poleward. Ocean pH dropping 0.1 units represents a 30% increase in acidity. Most organisms cannot adapt fast enough.
real_examples: Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (~56 MYA) - 5-8°C warming in 20,000 years
End-Permian hothouse (~252 MYA) - Equatorial temperatures hit 40°C; ocean temps reached 35°C

events.name: Sea Level Collapse
events.description: The seas retreat. Continental shelves—teeming with life—lie exposed as vast mudflats. Shallow epicontinental seas drain completely. Coastal ecosystems spanning millions of square kilometers simply vanish.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: Marine regression can drop sea levels 50-100+ meters. Causes include glaciation, tectonic uplift, or supercontinent formation reducing ocean basin volume.
real_examples: End-Ordovician regression (~445 MYA) - Glaciation drained shallow seas
End-Permian (~252 MYA) - Pangaea assembly destroyed 90% of continental shelf habitat

events.name: Reef Collapse
events.description: The rainforests of the sea crumble. Coral bleaching cascades across tropical waters. Carbonate production halts; the intricate architecture that housed 25% of marine species dissolves into rubble.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: Reef-building organisms require narrow temperature, pH, and light conditions. After collapse events, 'reef gaps' lasting 5-10 million years appear in the fossil record.
real_examples: Late Devonian (~372 MYA) - Stromatoporoid-coral reefs vanished for 100 million years
End-Triassic (~201 MYA) - First scleractinian corals nearly wiped out

events.name: Gamma Ray Burst
events.description: A dying star screams across the cosmos. Invisible radiation bathes Earth for ten seconds—long enough to strip away half the ozone layer. UV radiation surges; the food chain collapses from the top down.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: A GRB within 6,000 light-years could halve Earth's ozone. Nitrogen oxides from atmospheric ionization would create acid rain. UV-B increases 3-5x for years afterward.
real_examples: End-Ordovician (~445 MYA) - Hypothesized GRB contribution to glaciation
WR 104 (present) - Wolf-Rayet star 8,000 ly away could produce a GRB aimed at Earth

events.name: Methane Pulse
events.description: Frozen methane buried in seafloor sediments awakens. Clathrates destabilize and erupt, flooding the atmosphere with greenhouse gas 80x more potent than CO2. Oceans warm and acidify in decades.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: Methane clathrates store 10,000+ gigatons of carbon. Warming oceans can trigger runaway release. Methane oxidizes to CO2 over decades, prolonging warming.
real_examples: PETM (~56 MYA) - Carbon isotope spike suggests massive methane release
End-Permian (~252 MYA) - Siberian volcanism may have destabilized Arctic clathrates

events.name: Supercontinent Drought
events.description: Continents collide into a single landmass. Interior regions lie thousands of kilometers from any ocean; monsoons cannot penetrate. Hyper-arid deserts expand across half the globe.
events.effect: Binary extinction check
events.science: Supercontinent interiors experience extreme continentality: seasonal temperature swings of 50°C+ and near-zero precipitation. Only coast-huggers and burrowers survive.
real_examples: Permian Pangaea (~280-250 MYA) - Central deserts larger than modern Sahara
Rodinia interior (~1 BYA) - Extreme aridity before snowball Earth

events.name: Oxygen Surge
events.description: Photosynthesis wins. Atmospheric oxygen climbs past 25%, then 30%. Metabolic fires burn hotter; gigantism becomes possible. Dragonflies grow to the size of hawks; amphibians reach crocodile proportions.
events.effect: All players gain +2 alleles. [Insect] and [Amphibian] may place +2 markers.
events.science: Oxygen sets the upper limit on body size for tracheal breathers (insects) and influences metabolic efficiency for all aerobic life. Peak O2 enables maximum body plans.
real_examples: Carboniferous oxygen peak (~300 MYA) - O2 reached 35%; Meganeura had 70cm wingspans
Cambrian oxygenation (~540 MYA) - O2 crossed 15%, triggering animal radiation

events.name: New Frontier
events.description: Terra incognita emerges. Whether newly formed land, freshly thawed tundra, or previously toxic environments rendered habitable—empty niches await colonizers bold enough to claim them.
events.effect: Add 2 new tiles of player's choice. First to claim gets +3 alleles.
events.science: Ecological opportunity is evolution's accelerant. With no competitors or predators, colonizers can radiate freely. Early arrivals gain first-mover advantages that persist for millions of years.
real_examples: Silurian-Devonian land colonization (~420 MYA) - Empty continents awaited pioneers
Hawaiian Islands (~5 MYA to present) - Each new island spawns endemic radiations

events.name: Adaptive Radiation
events.description: Nature abhors a vacuum. Following extinction or the opening of new habitat, survivors explode into diverse forms. Lineages that were marginal yesterday become dominant tomorrow.
events.effect: All players may evolve one trait at half cost (round down).
events.science: Radiation events compress millions of years of evolution into geological instants. Released from competition, survivors diversify into body forms never seen before.
real_examples: Post-K-Pg mammal radiation (~66-50 MYA) - Shrew-sized ancestors became whales, bats, primates
Cambrian Explosion (~540-520 MYA) - Most animal phyla appear within 20 million years

events.name: Ozone Shield
events.description: The sky becomes a shield. Oxygen builds an ozone layer that blocks DNA-shredding ultraviolet radiation. For the first time, life can venture onto land without instant sunburn death.
events.effect: Players with [Terrestrial] traits gain +2 alleles. Land tiles give +1 marker.
events.science: UV-C radiation destroys DNA in seconds of direct exposure. The ozone layer absorbs 97-99% of harmful UV. Without it, only underwater or underground life is possible.
real_examples: Great Oxygenation Event (~2.4 BYA) - Ozone layer first forms
Silurian-Devonian (~420 MYA) - UV levels drop enough for land colonization

events.name: Predator Decline
events.description: The wolves are gone. Apex predators collapse, and trophic cascades ripple down the food web. Herbivore and detrivore populations explode. For once, the meek inherit the Earth.
events.effect: Players without [Predator] tag gain +3 alleles and +1 marker.
events.science: Removing top predators triggers mesopredator release and prey population booms. Without predation pressure, prey can invest energy in reproduction rather than defense.
real_examples: Post-K-Pg (~66 MYA) - No large terrestrial predators for 10 million years
Early Triassic (~252-247 MYA) - Predator guilds took 5 MY to recover from Great Dying

events.name: Mutualism Boom
events.description: Cooperation pays dividends. Symbiotic relationships intensify: pollinators and flowers coevolve, gut microbiomes become essential, and cleaning stations become social hubs. Together, everyone thrives.
events.effect: Players with [Pollinator] or [Social] tags gain +4 alleles.
events.science: Mutualism is an evolutionary innovation that increases fitness for all parties. The most successful organisms often owe their dominance to their symbiotic partners.
real_examples: Angiosperm-insect coevolution (~130-100 MYA) - Flowers and pollinators radiate together
Mycorrhizal revolution (~450 MYA) - Fungi enable plant colonization of land

events.name: Flowering Revolution
events.description: Petals unfurl across the planet. Angiosperms transform landscapes, offering nectar, fruit, and shelter. Pollinators diversify explosively; new forest structures create vertical niches.
events.effect: Players with [Pollinator] or [Arboreal] traits may evolve one trait at -2 cost. All such players gain +3 alleles.
events.science: Angiosperms evolved ~140 MYA and dominate today with 300,000+ species. Their fast reproduction and coevolution with pollinators drove the Cretaceous Terrestrial Revolution.
real_examples: Cretaceous Terrestrial Revolution (~100 MYA) - Angiosperms overtake gymnosperms
Eocene fruit forests (~50 MYA) - Primates radiate alongside fruiting trees

events.name: Nutrient Upwelling
events.description: The deep ocean gives back. Cold, nutrient-rich currents surge toward the surface, triggering massive plankton blooms. Fish schools darken the water; whales converge from across the globe.
events.effect: Players with [Aquatic] tags gain +3 alleles and may place +2 markers on ocean/sea tiles.
events.science: Upwelling zones cover <1% of ocean area but produce 50% of global fish catch. Nutrient-rich water supports food chains from phytoplankton to apex predators.
real_examples: Humboldt Current (ongoing) - Peru's anchovy fishery, world's largest
Monterey Bay (~15 MYA to present) - Upwelling drives extraordinary marine biodiversity

events.name: Forest Canopy Boom
events.description: Forests surge skyward. Warming climate and abundant CO2 drive explosive tree growth. Multi-layered canopies create new ecological theaters; arboreal niches multiply.
events.effect: Players with [Arboreal] or [Terrestrial] tags gain +2 alleles. Forest tiles produce double control bonus this era.
events.science: Forest canopies add vertical dimension to ecosystems. A single rainforest tree can host 1,000+ species. Canopy specialists evolve unique adaptations found nowhere else.
real_examples: Carboniferous forests (~350-300 MYA) - First true forests, trees 50m tall
Paleocene-Eocene rainforests (~55 MYA) - Tropical forests reached polar latitudes

events.name: Island Archipelago
events.description: Volcanoes breach the waves. A chain of new islands offers isolation laboratories for evolution. Each island becomes its own experiment; endemic species proliferate.
events.effect: Add 2 Coast tiles to the board. First player to occupy each gains +2 alleles and +1 marker.
events.science: Island biogeography shows that isolation + area determine species richness. Founder effects and genetic drift accelerate divergence from mainland ancestors.
real_examples: Hawaiian Islands (~5 MYA to present) - 1,000+ endemic species from handful of colonizers
Galápagos (~5 MYA) - Darwin's finches: 18 species from one ancestor

events.name: Continental Drift
events.description: The ground moves. Tectonic plates shift continents across latitudes, connecting or sundering populations. Seaways open and close; migration routes appear and vanish over millions of years.
events.effect: Shuffle 3 random tiles and replace with new tiles. All players may move 2 markers for free.
events.science: Plates move 2-15 cm/year—about as fast as fingernails grow. Over 100 million years, that's 2,000+ km. Continental configuration drives ocean currents, climate, and biogeography.
real_examples: Pangaea breakup (~200-150 MYA) - Atlantic Ocean opens; dinosaur provinces diverge
Great American Interchange (~3 MYA) - Panama land bridge connects two continents

events.name: Climate Shift
events.description: Weather patterns rewrite themselves. Ocean currents reorganize; prevailing winds shift; rainfall redistributes. Forests march poleward while deserts expand. Old habitats fade; new ones crystallize.
events.effect: Flip 2 tiles to new biome types. Affected players may relocate markers to adjacent tiles.
events.science: Climate zones can shift 100-500 km per 1°C global temperature change. Species must migrate, adapt, or die. Most climate shifts are gradual; some are geologically instantaneous.
real_examples: Eocene-Oligocene transition (~34 MYA) - Antarctica freezes; global cooling begins
Mid-Miocene Climatic Optimum (~17-14 MYA) - Warmest period in last 35 million years

events.name: Biome Transition
events.description: The landscape transforms. One ecosystem type gradually yields to another—forests to grasslands, wetlands to deserts. Generalists adapt; specialists scramble or perish.
events.effect: Convert 2 Forest tiles to Grassland OR vice versa. Players with matching traits gain +2 alleles.
events.science: Biome boundaries are set by temperature, precipitation, and CO2. When these change, biomes migrate. The rise of C4 grasses revolutionized terrestrial ecosystems.
real_examples: Miocene grassland expansion (~20-10 MYA) - C4 grasses enabled savanna ecosystems
Sahara pump (~10,000 year cycle) - Green Sahara and desert phases alternate

events.name: Arms Race
events.description: Predators and prey lock into evolutionary combat. Each adaptation spawns a counter-adaptation. Shells thicken; jaws strengthen; venom becomes deadlier; speed increases. The Red Queen runs faster.
events.effect: All [Predator] and [Armored] traits cost -1 allele this era.
events.science: The Red Queen hypothesis: species must constantly evolve just to maintain relative fitness. Predator-prey arms races drive some of evolution's most dramatic innovations.
real_examples: Mesozoic Marine Revolution (~200-65 MYA) - Shell-crushing predators drove prey to burrow, armor, flee
Cambrian arms race (~540-520 MYA) - Eyes, jaws, and shells evolve rapidly

events.name: Niche Partitioning
events.description: Competition breeds specialization. Rather than fight for the same resources, species divide the pie. Some feed by day, others by night; some eat leaves, others fruit; some climb, others dig.
events.effect: Players with 3+ unique tags gain +2 alleles. All other players gain +1 allele.
events.science: Competitive exclusion principle: two species cannot indefinitely occupy the same niche. The result is character displacement and resource partitioning.
real_examples: Darwin's finches - Beak shapes partition seeds by size
African grazers - Zebras eat tall grass; wildebeest eat medium; gazelles eat short

events.name: Glacial Retreat
events.description: Ice gives way. Glaciers pull back from their maximum extent, revealing scoured rock and fresh soil. Meltwater lakes form; pioneer species race northward. New territories open for colonization.
events.effect: Convert 1 Ice tile to Grassland. All players may move 2 markers for free.
events.science: Deglaciation exposes land at ~100-500m/year. Pioneer species (lichens, grasses) arrive within decades. Full forest succession takes centuries to millennia.
real_examples: End of last Ice Age (~11,700 ya) - Ice retreated from Chicago to Hudson Bay in 5,000 years
Ordovician deglaciation (~445-444 MYA) - Rapid warming triggered post-glacial radiation

events.name: Monsoon Shift
events.description: The rains move. Seasonal wind patterns reorganize, bringing floods to some regions and drought to others. River systems shift course; ecosystems depending on predictable rainfall must adapt or migrate.
events.effect: Swap 2 random Forest and Desert tiles. Players with markers on affected tiles may relocate them.
events.science: Monsoons are driven by land-sea temperature contrasts. Changes in continental position, ocean currents, or ice coverage can strengthen, weaken, or redirect monsoon systems.
real_examples: African Humid Period (~15,000-5,000 ya) - Sahara was green with lakes and rivers
Indian monsoon intensification (~8 MYA) - Himalayan uplift strengthened seasonal rains

events.name: Predator Boom
events.description: Hunters ascend. Conditions favor predators: prey is abundant, competition is low, and new hunting strategies prove devastatingly effective. The top of the food chain gets crowded.
events.effect: All [Predator] traits cost -1 allele this era. Players with [Predator] tag gain +2 alleles.
events.science: Predator diversity peaks when prey populations support multiple hunting guilds. Competition drives niche partitioning: ambush vs pursuit, diurnal vs nocturnal, aquatic vs terrestrial.
real_examples: Eocene predator peak (~50-40 MYA) - Creodonts, mesonychids, and early carnivorans competed
Cretaceous marine predators (~100-66 MYA) - Mosasaurs, plesiosaurs, sharks coexisted
